title: (x) AudioMulch logo - Ad Sans, Frutiger {Yves, Dana}
author: cheshiredave

comments.content:
Although it looks a _lot_ like [Verdana](http://web.archive.org/web/20050524123535/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/microsoft/verdana/bold/), I don�t believe that the centre of Verdana�s �M� (where the diagonals meet) reaches the baseline.   
I also tried [FreeSet Demi](http://web.archive.org/web/20050524123535/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/paratype/free-set/pt-free-set-demi-bold/) but the �c� is too open and the centre of the �M� is too thick;   
 [Scylla Medium](http://web.archive.org/web/20050524123535/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/urw/scylla/medium/) but it seems too narrow, too short in its x height, and wrong dot over the �i�;   
 [Frutiger 65](http://web.archive.org/web/20050524123535/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/frutiger/65-bold/) but the �M� centre is too square, and the �c� is too open (and overall it seems a bit narrower than the sample).   
It�s _very_ close to many faces, but I can not yet find an exact match.   
   
cheers,   
Dana

Fantastic, thanks!   
   
Interestingly, I'm sure I can see what seems an excessive amount of round overshoot in Ad Sancs. This is particularly noticeable on larger sizes (seen here on the u, d and c, but not the o, although that is the same size). And that's not present on the AudioMulch logo.   
   
To me, it's unquestionably the same typeface though, and I can't believe the AudioMulch author would have tweaked his logo, so what would account for it? Two separately digitised versions?   
   
And oh yes, the c is quite different on the small text, I hadn't really looked as I was expecting it to be the same !   
   
I took your advice and registered, btw ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20050524123535im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)   
   
Cheers, Robin

Yves... too generous in sharing the id with me. He11, I even confused Frutiger with FreeSet. You deserve extra kindness and generosity, today.   
   
cheers,   
Dana
